title: Poly((lactic-co-glycolic acid)-b-lysine) and process for synthesizing a block copolymer of plga {poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid)} and pll (poly-e-cbz-l-lysine)

abstract: A method of synthesizing block or graft copolymers is provided. The method can include coupling a degradable polymer to a poly(amino acid) and then deprotecting the copolymer if the poly(amino acid) contains protected side chains. Block and graft copolymer compositions are provided. These compositions include PLGA-PLL block copolymers, PLGA-PLL-cbz block copolymers, block copolymers of a polyester with a carboxylic acid end group coupled to a poly(amino acid) with an amine group, and graft copolymers of a polyester with a carboxylic acid end group coupled to a poly(amino acid) with an amine group. The compositions may include therapeutic blends and formulation of block and graft copolymers.
claims:
1. A method of synthesizing a block or graft copolymer comprising: coupling a degradable polymer to a poly(amino acid) by combining the degradable polymer, the poly(amino acid), a solvent and a coupling catalyst to form a copolymer solution; and 
       isolating the copolymer by dialysis of the copolymer solution in water to form an isolated copolymer.
2. The method of claim 1, wherein the degradable polymer has a single carboxylic acid terminal group.

3. The method of claim 2, wherein the degradable polymer is Poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) with any weight ratio of lactide to glycolide, lactide to poly lactic acid, lactide to poly glycolic acid, or lactide to Poly(8-caprolactone).
4. The method of claim 1, wherein the degradable polymer has a single acyl terminal end group.

5. The method of claim 4, wherein the degradable polymer is poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) with any weight ratio of lactide to glycolide, lactide to poly lactic acid, lactide to poly glycolic acid, or lactide to Poly(8-caprolactone).
6. The method of claim 1, wherein the degradable polymer is polyester with a carboxylic acid end group.
7. The method of claim 1, wherein the poly(amino acid) has an amine terminal end group.
8. The method of claim 7, wherein the poly(amino acid) is poly(L- lysine) or poly(8-carbobenzoxy-L-lysine).
9. The method of claim 1, wherein the coupling catalyst is one or more selected from the group consisting of DCC/DMAP, DCC/DMAP/NHS, EDC/DMAP, Pybob, CDMT, and HATU.
10. The method of claim 1, wherein the coupling catalyst is DCC/DMAP/NHS.
11. The method of claim 1, wherein the solvent is selected from the group consisting of DMSO, DMF, dichloromethane, and chloroform.
12. The method of claim 1, wherein the solvent is DMSO.
13. The method of claim 1, wherein the water in the dialysis includes a mixture of DMSO and ethanol.
14. The method of claim 1 further comprising drying the isolated copolymer by lyophilization.
15. The method of claim 1 further comprising deprotecting the copolymer by DCM thin film if the poly (amino acid) contains protected side chains.

16. The method of claim 1 further comprising deprotecting the copolymer by DCM thin film if the poly (amino acid) contains protected side chains to yield a deprotected copolymer; 
       wherein the method further includes at least one of the coupling catalyst being DCC/DMAP/NHS, the solvent being DMSO, dialysis including a mixture of DMSO and ethanol, or drying the isolated copolymer by lyophillization.
17. The method of claim 16, wherein the time of deprotecting the copolymer is 30 minutes.
18. The method of claim 16 further comprising isolating the deprotected copolymer.
19. The method of claim 18 wherein isolating the deprotected copolymer includes purification by dilution in a solvent followed by washing and precipitation.
20. A composition comprising the product of the method of claim 1.
21. A composition comprising the product of the method of claim 15.
22. A composition comprising the product of the method of claim 16.
23. A composition comprising a block copolymer of poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) and poly(8-carbobenzoxy-L- Lysine).
24. The composition of claim 23 further comprising cells and/or therapeutic agents for therapeutic implantation in the central nervous system or other medically relevant anatomic site.
25. A composition comprising a block copolymer of Poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) and Poly (L- Lysine).
26. The composition of claim 25 further comprising cells and/or therapeutic agents for therapeutic implantation in the central nervous system or other medically relevant anatomic site.
27. A composition comprising a block copolymer of a polyester with a carboxylic acid end group coupled to a poly(amino acid) with an amine group.
28. The composition of claim 27 further comprising cells and/or therapeutic agents for therapeutic implantation in the central nervous system or other medically relevant anatomic site.
29. A composition comprising a graft copolymer of a polyester with a carboxylic acid end group coupled to a poly(amino acid) with an amine group.
30. A composition comprising a blend of i) poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid), and ii) a block copolymer of poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) and poly(8-carbobenzoxy- L-lysine).
31. The composition of claim 30 further comprising at least one of cells or therapeutic agents.
32. A composition comprising a blend of i) poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid), and ii) a block copolymer of poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) and poly (L-ly sine).
33. The composition of claim 32 further comprising at least one of cells or therapeutic agents.
34. A composition comprising a blend of i) poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) and, ii) a block copolymer of a polyester with a carboxylic acid end group coupled to a poly (amino acid) with an amine group.
35. The composition of claim 34 further comprising at least one of cells or therapeutic agents.
36. A composition comprising a blend of i) poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) and, ii) a graft copolymer of a polyester with a carboxylic acid end group coupled to a poly (amino acid) with an amine group.
37. The composition of claim 36 further comprising at least one of cells or therapeutic agents.

38. A method of treating a patient comprising 
       implanting the composition of any of claims 20— 37 at a medically relevant anatomic site.

39. The method of claim 38, wherein the medically relevant anatomic site is one selected from the group consisting of the central nervous system, the peripheral nervous system, organs, an intra peritoneal site, and the musculoskeletal system.

40. The method of claim 39, wherein the medically relevant anatomic site is a site of injury in one selected from the group consisting of the central nervous system, the peripheral nervous system, organs, an intra peritoneal site, and the musculoskeletal system.
